Dennis G. Wilson
ISAE-SUPAERO, University of Toulouse
dennis.wilson@isae-supaero.fr

Abstract

Coastal zones are facing increasing pressures due to climate change and growing population densities in coastal areas worldwide. Accurate forecasting of coastal zone evolution is crucial for coastal managers in risk assessment and mitigation. Recent advances in artificial intelligence and remote sensing enable the development of automatic large-scale analysis methodologies based on observation data. This work utilizes a novel satellite-derived shoreline forecasting dataset and two variants of the Encoder-Decoder neural network, UNet, to predict shoreline change based on spatio-temporal information. We analyze the importance of including spatial context at the prediction step and find that it significantly enhances model performance. The UNet and UNetLSTM models presented here achieve significant global forecast correlation scores of 0.66 and 0.77, respectively.

1. Introduction

Coastal zones around the world are facing increased natural and anthropogenic pressures, and understanding their evolution is critical in various scenarios, including coastal risk assessment and mitigation. Shoreline evolution forecasting is a crucial element in coastal science, aiming to improve our understanding of and ability to predict coastal erosion and its potential impacts on the coast. Much of our current knowledge of coastal evolution comes from the study of well-documented coastal sites where frequent field surveys have been ongoing for multiple years. However, due to the high cost of in-situ field surveys, the state and evolution of these systems are not well-known in many areas of the world. Space-borne Earth Observation missions offer the potential for studying coastal systems at a global scale and high temporal frequencies, but present new technical challenges and require the development of new methodologies for information extraction and processing.

Machine learning (ML) is a family of artificial intelligence algorithms that aim to automatically approximate the relationships between inputs and outputs by maximizing or minimizing an objective function over a labeled dataset of training samples. Recent developments in ML have led to significant advancements in various scientific domains. Due to the continuous stream of high-dimensional data recorded by multiple Earth Observation satellite constellations, ML has seen wide adoption in remote sensing data processing pipelines and has been used to augment or replace existing image and signal processing-based analysis.

A large body of work exists in the coastal science literature on shoreline forecasting, ranging from physics-based approaches to data-driven techniques. Deep learning-based models are often found competitive with physics-based and traditional forecasting techniques and offer desirable properties in large-scale shoreline analysis. However, training accurate deep learning models requires the availability of representative training data that allows the models to generalize to previously unseen conditions.

In this work, we utilize a novel global-scale dataset of satellite-derived shorelines and their corresponding shoreline change drivers to train and test a spatio-temporal approach to predicting shoreline change based on deep learning. We extend the Encoder-Decoder convolutional neural network (UNet) to include a temporal unit (LSTM) to learn spatio-temporal patterns in shoreline forcing and shoreline response. To our knowledge, this work presents the first steps towards a data-driven method for global shoreline prediction based on spatio-temporal data.

2. Global Shorelines Dataset

This study utilizes a satellite-derived dataset of global monthly shoreline position time series that spans 25 years (1994 to 2019) and covers 6841 coastal points around the globe. The dataset includes global datasets of shoreline change drivers, including coastal waves, sea level anomaly, and regional river discharge. The methodology used to derive shoreline positions from satellite imagery involves segmenting satellite imagery into land and sea surfaces using the Normal Difference Water Index (NDWI) maps. The coastline position is identified as the interface between land and sea. The Google Earth Engine was used to process a large amount of satellite data from the Landsat 5, 7, and 8 missions to create a time series of global coastline evolution. The extracted shorelines are aggregated to a monthly scale using the monthly median shoreline position. Multiple techniques were used to derive the shoreline change drivers time series, including satellite altimetry.
